properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong northwest winds gusting to 90 kilometres per hour are expected Saturday. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to QCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #QCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant snowfall and wind expected beginning Sunday afternoon. Total snowfall: 15 to 30 cm. Maximum wind gusts: 80 km/h. Stronger coastal gusts possible. Locations: southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: Sunday afternoon through Monday morning. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across eastern Newfoundland Sunday afternoon. Strong winds and blowing snow will develop overnight Sunday and continue into Monday morning. Snow and blowing snow will result in poor visibility which may impact Monday morning commuters. Conditions are expected to improve near noon Monday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2020-01-04T11:23:54-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T19:24:54-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0623173906.2020

properties.Title: Winter Storm Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Significant amounts of snow are expected. A strong Pacific storm will bring 30 to 60 cm of snow over inland sections of the north coast. Snow will continue today over the inland sections of the north coast. The snow is expected to ease and become mixed with rain tonight. ### Rapidly accumulating snow will make travel difficult. Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T03:48:11-00:00

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong winter storm will give significant winds to the west coast of Vancouver Island this afternoon. Southeast winds will increase throughout the morning and eventually peak at 80 km/h for exposed sections of West Vancouver Island, particularly for the northern portion of the region. The winds will diminish late this evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

Winds will diminish late this evening. ### High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A storm moving across the BC interior has brought heavy snow to the Prince George region this morning. Snowfall amounts near 15 cm have been reported. The snow is expected to continue early this afternoon, with an additional 5 cm possible. However, as warm air moves into the region, snow will change to rain this afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 30 cm is expected. A strong Pacific storm will move through the region tonight and Saturday. Rain will begin falling on the Coquihalla Highway this evening and then quickly transition to snow by late evening. Snow heavy at times will fall through the night before tapering slightly on Saturday. Late Saturday evening the snow will change over to flurries. A total of 20 to 30 cm of snow is possible depending on how quickly the transition from rain to snow occurs, ### Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T10:44:37-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T18:45:37-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3468190971.2020
Area: Coquihalla Highway - Hope to Merritt
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 20 to 25 cm is expected. An approaching winter storm will spread snow to the northern interior today. Snow at times heavy is expected for the Bulkley Valley, McGregor, and Williston regions. Snow will continue today with snowfall amounts of up to 20 to 25 cm by this evening. Meanwhile Highway 97 - Pine Pass will see snow continuing today with up to 25 cm of snow by this evening. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Weather in the mountains can change suddenly resulting in hazardous driving conditions. Road conditions are available at www.drivebc.ca. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A long period of snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. An approaching winter storm will spread snow to Fort Nelson and the B.C. Peace today. Snow at times heavy will continue for the B.C. Peace region and spread north toward Fort Nelson this afternoon. Snowfall amounts near 10 cm are generally expected. However, the snow will be heavier near the Rockies, including Chetwynd and Hudson Hope, where 20 cm are forecast. Up to 15 cm will fall along the Alaska Highway over higher terrain south of Fort Nelson. Snow should end early Saturday morning for the Peace region and will continue through midday Saturday near Fort Nelson. ### Visibility may be suddenly reduced at times in heavy snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Snowfall Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall with total amounts of 15 to 20 cm is expected. A low pressure centre crossing the North Coast will bring a period of heavy snow to the Stewart region. Snow will begin this morning with a few centimetres expected today. In the evening, the snow will intensify and 15 cm is expected to fall through the evening and overnight. ### Surfaces such as highways, roads, walkways and parking lots may become difficult to navigate due to accumulating snow. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong Pacific storm will bring strong winds to southern sections of Howe Sound including Bowen Island late this afternoon and early this evening. Strong southeasterly winds of 70 gusting 90 km/h will develop later this afternoon over southern sections of Howe Sound including Bowen Island. The winds will ease late this evening, but will remain brisk into Saturday morning. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow expected on Sunday. Location: Nova Scotia. Timing: Sunday into Sunday night. Remarks: A disturbance will approach the Maritimes Saturday night giving developing snow. In the west, the precipitation will start as rain and then change to snow Sunday morning. The highest amounts are expected over eastern sections of the province where the snow will develop Sunday morning and persist into the evening. General snowfall amounts of 5 to 10 cm are expected however over eastern regions 10 cm or more are possible. Additionally, strong northerly winds will develop on Sunday and combine with the fresh snow to create reduced visibility in blowing snow that will persist into Sunday night. Accumulating snow and blowing snow will make travel difficult on Sunday, motorists are advised to exercise caution. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NSstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NSStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T10:56:40-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T18:57:40-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3227016087.2020

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected or occurring. A strong Pacific storm will bring a brief period of significant wind to the south coast on tonight and Saturday morning. Southeast winds will gradually strengthen throughout today, particularly for areas near Haro Strait and the Strait of Georgia. Late in the evening winds will briefly reach 70 km/h before becoming southerly, and briefly spread inland to Langley to Abbotsford. In the early morning hours of Saturday the winds will shift once more to southwesterly. For areas near Juan de Fuca Strait, winds will again reach 70 km/h. Winds for areas near Boundary Bay and southern Surrey will also remain strong. Winds will slowly ease through the Saturday afternoon. ### Loose objects may be tossed by the wind and cause injury or damage. High winds may toss loose objects or cause tree branches to break. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2020-01-04T07:38:11-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2020-01-03T15:39:11-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2659248014.2020

properties.Summary:
Description: Rain, at times heavy, is expected. A strong Pacific storm continues to impact the BC coast. Rain will persist through today. Total rainfall amounts are expected to be 100 to 150 mm for the Central Coast - coastal sections, West Vancouver Island and near Port Alice on North Vancouver Island. Heavy rain will ease tonight but light rain will continue into Saturday. ### Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.

properties.Summary:

The rain will taper off to a few showers near midday. ### Heavy downpours can cause flash floods and water pooling on roads. Localized flooding in low-lying areas is possible. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
